body: Do you see a difference in behavior between T4 and 1080 even with just the C++ API (sans JNI)? ORT doesn't have a different execution path on T4 cards.
Is it the lack of IoBinding support that made you choose to write your own Java interface rather than use the built in one, or something else?

AFAIK we don't have any memory leaks in ORT. You may try turning off arena and memory pattern. SessionOptions::DisableCpuMemArena and SessionOptions::DisableMemPattern.
Please provide a reproducible program along with the model file.

> Is it the lack of IoBinding support that made you choose to write your own Java interface rather than use the built in one, or something else?

Our wrapper is on a higher level (AI level, e.g. object detection) and also has many other features unrelated to models, e.g. video decoding.
I do not have T4 handy. Try to take `memory_info` and `input` out of the loop and see what changes. Also can you try running the same code on CPU, please?

> I do not have T4 handy. Try to take `memory_info` and `input` out of the loop and see what changes. Also can you try running the same code on CPU, please?

Just did the following tests:
1. Run on CPU (`memory_info` and `input` still inside the loop): no leaks.
2. Run on T4 GPU, move `memory_info` and `input` out of the loop: leaks fast, about 100MB/s~200MB/s
    * BTW, in a real world situation, `input` cannot be moved out side of the loop unless IoBinding is used, because every input is different.

@torshie you have submitted a very good bug report. I have installed a Nuget package 1.8.1 and build your test executable (one of the include paths is broken in the package, but easy to correct). I am not seeing any leaks with my GPU, as you probably expected.

With T4 available, you may have to investigate it so the product and the community can benefit from your work. Let me know if there is any more help I can provide.

Can you turn on leak sanitizer while compiling your program for T4 ? 

A while back, there was a very similar issue of memory leaks reproing only on Linux but not on Windows (for the same CUDA and CuDNN versions). Tracked it down to some issue in CuDNN on Linux that time:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9969784/140402400-be849af6-9fb0-42ab-a654-a29c18f81a38.png)

It was fixed by using a later version of CuDNN with the same CUDA version. 

I also remember that the leak happened while running a "fused" Conv node - the fusion only occurred when the graph optimization level was >= ORT_ENABLE_EXTENDED. Keeping the graph optimization level ORT_ENABLE_BASIC didn't trigger that specific fusion and the faulty CuDNN call didn't come into the picture.

@hariharans29 Wala! Leak sanitizer reported memory leaks (I almost forgot leak sanitizer, after running into its bugs a couple times):
Command: `./leak_debug leak.onnx 10`
```

```

Also the program doesn't leak when running at ORT_ENABLE_BASIC optimization!  Nvidia disappointed me again.

@torshie - Thanks. This is the same leak then. An internal team had reported this a while back and we spent some time to investigate and narrow it down. A [fused Conv](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/74dc48f61c07c144375693bc0d9e3dde13da5e02/onnxruntime/core/optimizer/graph_transformer_utils.cc#L198) node (that is how the graph optimization level comes in) was the source of those leaks but we couldn't find what was wrong in our client code that calls into CuDNN and they just went away with a newer CuDNN version. CC: @RandySheriffH

@torshie : will reproduce your case with listed configurations - the culprit might be the CUDNN version, upgrade should help.
Allow me confirm this and propose a solution.

> @torshie : will reproduce your case with listed configurations - the culprit might be the CUDNN version, upgrade should help. Allow me confirm this and propose a solution.

You're right. After upgrading the docker image to version 11.4.2-cudnn8-runtime-ubuntu20.04, the leak is gone.
@torshie: thanks for the confirmation, I am testing a few versions, will doc this in coming release.
